title: When bad engineering makes a natural disaster even worse
description: What did the world learn from the devastating earthquake that struck Haiti in 2010? That shoddy buildings and bad planning can make a terrible situation even worse. "Haiti was not a natural disaster," says TED Fellow Peter Haas. "It was a disaster of engineering." The solution: Help builders on the ground get trained in modern engineering practices, so they can rebuild their country stronger, brick by brick.
author: Peter Haas
keywords: TED, talks, TED Fellows, architecture, business, disaster relief, global issues, natural disaster, technology
